liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The final report of the Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability has been tabled in federal parliament. After an inquiry lasting four-and-a-half-years, the royal commission has made 222 recommendations for change. Commissioners said: "Inclusion involves social transformation that enables people with disability to live, learn, work, play, create and engage alongside people without disability”. Disability advocates have been eagerly awaiting the findings and are hoping for reform across areas like education, employment, and housing. The royal commission began in 2019 and held 32 public hearings, which scrutinised the experiences of the 4.4 million Australians who live with disability. Social Services Minister Amanda Rishworth and NDIS Minister Bill Shorten will hold a media conference later today. You can continue reading this story by the Specialist Reporting Team's Evan Young and Celina Edmonds, with national disability affairs reporter Nas Campanella at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Disability royal commission makes 222 recommendations for change

featuredLink.title: Disability royal commission hands down final report with 222 recommendations for change

props.alt: Silhouettes of four people are seen in front of a purple background and a set of scales of justice

children.content: (ABC News: Emma Machan)
The final report of the Royal Commission into Violence, Abuse, Neglect and Exploitation of People with Disability has been tabled in federal parliament.
After an inquiry lasting four-and-a-half-years, the royal commission has made 222 recommendations for change.
Commissioners said:
"Inclusion involves social transformation that enables people with disability to live, learn, work, play, create and engage alongside people without disability”.
Disability advocates have been eagerly awaiting the findings and are hoping for reform across areas like education, employment, and housing.
The royal commission began in 2019 and held 32 public hearings, which scrutinised the experiences of the 4.4 million Australians who live with disability.
Social Services Minister Amanda Rishworth and NDIS Minister Bill Shorten will hold a media conference later today.
You can continue reading this story by the Specialist Reporting Team's
Evan Young
and
Celina Edmonds
, with national disability affairs reporter
Nas Campanella
at the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister has paid his respects to those who have died in the line of duty on National Police Remembrance Day. "We express our gratitude for their service and vow to never forget their sacrifice," Anthony Albanese said in a statement. "Behind every officer is a family and community who are in our thoughts. It is a heavy burden to know that your loved one is risking their life at work, and the grief and sorrow of loss is immense." Today, the Queensland constables Rachel McCrow and Matthew Arnold are being honoured at National Police Remembrance Day services across the country, the first time since they were killed in an ambush at Wieambilla in December 2022.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM pays respects on National Police Remembrance Day

featuredLink.title: 'Bright, brave' police officers killed in ambush to be honoured as families miss them 'every day'

children.content: The prime minister has paid his respects to those who have died in the line of duty on National Police Remembrance Day.
"We express our gratitude for their service and vow to never forget their sacrifice," Anthony Albanese said in a statement.
"Behind every officer is a family and community who are in our thoughts. It is a heavy burden to know that your loved one is risking their life at work, and the grief and sorrow of loss is immense."
Today,
the Queensland constables
Rachel McCrow
and
Matthew Arnold
are being honoured at National Police Remembrance Day services across the country, the first time since they were killed in an ambush at Wieambilla in December 2022.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The helicopter involved in the fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays will no longer be used by the defence force. Four defence members were killed when an MRH-90 Taipan helicopter crashed in July. The fleet was grounded after the incident and investigations are ongoing. In a statement, Defence Minister Richard Marles has confirmed the Taipans will not return to flying operations before their planned withdrawal date of December 2024. You can continue reading this story by political reporter Georgia Roberts below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal defence crash retired early

featuredLink.title: Australian Defence Force MRH-90 Taipan helicopters involved in fatal defence crash retired early

props.alt: Taipan helicopter kicks up dust as it takes off.

children.content: (Supplied: Department of Defence)
The helicopter involved in the fatal military training exercise in the Whitsundays will
no longer be used by the defence force.
Four defence members were killed when an MRH-90 Taipan helicopter crashed in July
The fleet was grounded after the incident and investigations are ongoing.
In a statement, Defence Minister
Richard Marles
has confirmed the Taipans will not return to flying operations before their planned withdrawal date of December 2024.
You can continue reading this story by political reporter
Georgia Roberts
below.

props.synopsis: The US version of FairWork has launched a lawsuit against Elon Musk's Tesla, alleging "widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees". Meanwhile, the founder of Evergrande is under police watch, stoking fears the Chinese property giant is about to tank. Read all about today's business news on our live blog.

title.children: US regulator sues Tesla for 'racial harassment and retaliation', while Chinese property giant Evergrande's shares halted

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some big news out of China. Shares in the Chinese property giant Evergrande have been halted. It has been battling solvency issues for at least a year. Its shares were halted after the developer said its founder Hui Ka Yan is being investigated over suspected "illegal crimes" and is under police watch. It's leading to more concerns from creditors about its ability to pay back enormous amounts of debt. Here is some copy from the news wire service Reuters: The world's most indebted property developer with more than $300 billion in total liabilities did not say whether Hui Ka Yan was still in a position to run the company, or what crimes he is being investigated for. The news signals for the first time that authorities could hold the billionaire Evergrande founder accountable for the developer's financial woes, which have ripped through the property sector that accounts for roughly a quarter of the Chinese economy. Deepening turmoil in China's debt-laden property sector is threatening to undermine Beijing's efforts to get the sputtering economy back on more solid footing, and raising fears among investors of a spillover into the country's banking system. The latest development is a major blow to China's once top-selling developer that has lurched from one crisis to another since its cash squeeze became public in 2021 and it defaulted on its offshore debt obligations later that year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chinese property giant Evergrande's shares halted

children.content: Some big news out of China.
Shares in the Chinese property giant Evergrande have been halted. It has been battling solvency issues for at least a year.
Its shares were halted after the developer said its founder Hui Ka Yan is being investigated over suspected "illegal crimes" and is under police watch.
It's leading to more concerns from creditors about its ability to pay back enormous amounts of debt.
Here is some copy from the news wire service Reuters:

The world's most indebted property developer with more than $300 billion in total liabilities did not say whether Hui Ka Yan was still in a position to run the company, or what crimes he is being investigated for.

The news signals for the first time that authorities could hold the billionaire Evergrande founder accountable for the developer's financial woes, which have ripped through the property sector that accounts for roughly a quarter of the Chinese economy.

Deepening turmoil in China's debt-laden property sector is threatening to undermine Beijing's efforts to get the sputtering economy back on more solid footing, and raising fears among investors of a spillover into the country's banking system.

The latest development is a major blow to China's once top-selling developer that has lurched from one crisis to another since its cash squeeze became public in 2021 and it defaulted on its offshore debt obligations later that year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Content warning: This post features discussion of racial abuse. Elon Musk's Tesla is being sued by the US version of FairWork for "tolerating widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees" from at least 2015 until today. The lawsuit was just filed by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The regulator's suit contains some very concerning allegations that workers in its California factory endured racial abuse, stereotyping, and vilificaton including a range of racial slurs. "Slurs were used casually and openly in high-traffic areas and at worker hubs," they allege. It further alleges that workers faced graffiti around the factory that depicted racial abuse, "including variations of the N-word, swastikas, threats, and nooses, on desks and other equipment". This graffiti was even allegedly found on new electric cars as they were rolling off the production line. Further, it found people who raised objections to this, faced retaliation including being fired. The case was lodged by the EEOC's office in the tech hub of Silicon Valley and is being led by former FBI lawyer James Baker. Tesla has been contacted for comment. This suit follows another lawsuit by Californian-based regulators about similiar issues. Earlier this year, Tesla agreed to pay one worker several million dollars after a federal jury found it failed to prevent severe racial harassment at the Californian plant. Read more of the suit here .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tesla sued by US regulator for 'racial harassment and retaliation'

children.content: Content warning: This post features discussion of racial abuse.
Elon Musk's Tesla is being sued by the US version of FairWork for "tolerating widespread and ongoing racial harassment of its Black employees" from at least 2015 until today.
The lawsuit was just filed by the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
The regulator's suit contains some very concerning allegations that workers in its California factory endured racial abuse, stereotyping, and vilificaton including a range of racial slurs.
"Slurs were used casually and openly in high-traffic areas and at worker hubs," they allege.
It further alleges that workers faced graffiti around the factory that depicted racial abuse, "including variations of the N-word, swastikas, threats, and nooses, on desks and other equipment".
This graffiti was even allegedly found on new electric cars as they were rolling off the production line.
Further, it found people who raised objections to this, faced retaliation including being fired.
The case was lodged by the EEOC's office in the tech hub of Silicon Valley and is being led by former FBI lawyer James Baker.
Tesla has been contacted for comment.

This suit follows another lawsuit by Californian-based regulators about similiar issues. Earlier this year, Tesla agreed to pay one worker several million dollars after a federal jury found it failed to prevent severe racial harassment at the Californian plant.
Read
more of the suit here
